ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Information measures (e.g. entropy, divergence, mutual information), data processing inequalities, sufficient statistics, data compression (e.g. Huffman codes, universal codes), binary hypothesis testing, channel coding and capacity, rate-distortion theory
Information theory from a theoretical & statistical perspective.

Basic concepts in information theory (entropy, differential entropy, KL divergence, mutual information, data processing inequality, etc). Data compression, hypothesis testing (stein regime, chernoff regime), large deviation theory, data transmission, and applications to statistics theory (mutual information methods to prove minimax risk).
Very useful knowledge and techniques in information theory.

This course provides an extremely comprehensive introduction to information theory! I learned how to interpret problems in an information theoretic context, and come up with codes to solve various communication and compression problems!
Entropy, divergence, mutual information, Neyman-Pearson testing, lossy compression, lossless compression, coding theory, hypothesis testing
entropy theorem and mutual information. Kl divergence and compression theorem.
understanding of entropy, mutual information, divergence, data compression, channel coding, etc.
information theory
Information theory, data transmission bounds, channel coding bounds.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: very interesting material, challenging problem sets ======== Weaknesses: Prof. Wu lectures moved at too quick a pace at times
Prof. Wu is really great at this stuff. The strength is definitely the prof.
It is great!
Strengths: great textbook, very knowledgeable instructor; problem sets are well-designed and office hours are helpful. Weaknesses: none.

Strengths: You learn about a great diversity of topics that probably arent taught elsewhere in the S&DS department
Weaknesses: Yihongs speed of writing is insane. If you want to take paper notes and actually understand whats going on, that may not be possible. Some units (hypothesis testing specifically) felt a bit rushed since there was so much content

strength: wide coverage of relevant topics;
weakness: sometimes the instructor's handwriting on the board during class could be hard to read
speed is quite fast

The course covers a wide range of topics. It could be improved by moving to a larger classroom so students can see the whiteboard closer and more clearly. A neater and larger handwriting on the whiteboard would help a lot, especially to students sitting at the back.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, information theory is a very interesting field and presents unique insights on problems and concepts from related fields.
For those who are interested in information theory and want to challenge themselves, yes.
Yes! Taking this course will be rewarding.

Absolutely! This course is everything you want it to be and more. If you dont know much about information theory but are interested in anything related to the fundamental of how modern technology works, this is definitely a course worth taking.

Yes, if you get a head start on all the homework and are comfortable being lost in lecture, so long as you can clarify it later. Yihong is a really nice guy who is always eager to clarify concepts and share his personal experiences
Yes.
It's a great class and the instructor makes an effort to make the textbook accessible. Homework problems are well-designed so that they are a bit challenging but you also learn stuff from doing them.
yes
Yes. Elementary and advanced information theoretic tools are useful in a wide range of disciplines.
